abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed project is part of Phase I
            of a Twelve-Year Sea Defense Program, to provide protection
            against cyclical and local erosion and flooding by the sea
            of the fertile coastal plains, which lie below sea level.
            The project consists of: (a) construction of about 26,230
            feet of sea walls, including 21,230 feet in the East
            Demerara Coast and 5,000 feet in the West Demerara Coast;
            (b) purchase of hydrographic equipment, including one survey
            launch, to extend the scope of coastal erosion research and
            hydrographic studies; (c) preparation, by end of 1969, of an
            engineering and economic feasibility study of works needed
            to protect the Georgetown Esplanade; and (d) preparation, by
            1971, of a study of improved sea wall designs including
            necessary hydraulic model tests and possible construction
            methods, and of an economic/technical study for selecting
            priority areas to be protected by sea defense works from 1972.
